poem:
**At the Table**

In the whisper of potato peels,  
they gather—  
mothers, daughters,  
unspoken words  
thick as the stew  
bubbling over.  
Set the plates,  
pass the butter,  
sharp as secrets  
held under tongues—  
voices clash,  
black humor like smoke  
in the rooms of their homes—  
rising, falling,  
simmering in silence.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Consumed review – mothers and daughters clash in Women’s prize for playwriting winner Karis Kelly’s drama won the Women’s prize for playwriting in 2022 and you can see why. Set amid a family reunion dinner in Northern Ireland, only the women are present here. And in the way of many such theatrical reunions, it leads to an almighty blow-up, yet there is no hint of cliche. Kelly is a talented playwright navigating between black humour". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Consumed review – mothers and daughters clash in Women’s prize for playwriting winner Karis Kelly’s drama won the Women’s prize for playwriting in 2022 and you can see why. Set amid a family reunion dinner in Northern Ireland, only the women are present here. And in the way of many such theatrical reunions, it leads to an almighty blow-up, yet there is no hint of cliche. Kelly is a talented playwright navigating between black humour
